profile_positions.description:
As Equipment Engineer I'm responsible for providing and optimizing the servicemix - that is everything required for the maintenance of ASML's (extremely complex) machines at the customers.

In the first development phase of a product I give input in the requirements, and review proposed designs. In the second phase I define the spares, tools, and training materials that will be needed, and produce the service manuals and training materials. During the third phase I provide technical support for the service engineers, as they learn to work with the new machine. I also propose improvements to increase uptime.

From august to early november I was assigned to assist a more experienced Equipment Engineer, to learn basic EE-skills. In addition, I made the initial push for a new way of working to produce and maintain multiple, extremely large service manuals.

In early november I was transferred to another competency, and assigned to deliver a series of service manuals, for which no supporting technical documentation was available. While writing these, I encountered issues with the design, and started initiatives for design improvements.

From january onwards, I became the responsible Equipment Engineer for this entire subsystem. When a crash action was announced to homegenize safety warnings, I developed a way of working to minimze the workload from this action. After that, I piloted a human safety review process for safety manuals. The conclusions from this review contributed to a requirement from the program for another crash action, that all projects perform such a review.

May-june I spent a month at a customer, to provide training for the local service engineers, and to gain first-hand experience with maintenance in the field. I learned how maintenance actions are performed in practice, at 6 am after a 10 hr shift. I also came up with a simple solution to an equipment deficiency, which had existed for years at this particular customer.
profile_positions.title: Equipment Engineer

profile_positions.description:
MASTER THESIS
Improving a continuous measurement system for atmospheric oxygen and carbon dioxide.

The assignment consisted of the repair, evaluation and improving of a system for continuous measurements of atmospheric oxygen and carbon dioxide, in preparation for deployment at a remote location.
I was responsible for performing these tasks, with technical support from the institute’s technicians, but without supervision from anyone intimately familiar with the system.
I first focused on improving the system’s stability and ease of maintenance, by rewriting several of the routines used by its control program, in collaboration with a technician. In addition, I made some hardware changes for the same purpose.
To take advantage of the system’s improved stability, I reconfigured the calibration procedure, to simultaneously increase its accuracy and reduce its downtime from sample measurements. In addition, in cooperation with the glassblower I designed and implemented a cooling system with a lower internal volume while maintaining backwards compatibility with similar systems, to reduce the recovery time from switches by more than 50%.
The result was a much more reliable system. In addition, calibration accuracy was improved by up to at least 30 per meg for oxygen. Daily uptime for sample measurements with maximum precision was increased from 14,5 hour to 21,5 hour. Improvements were applied to an existing, similar system as well.
During this assignment, I gained experience with Delphi, with gas handling for precision measurements in a Swagelok-based system, and with custom-designed glass devices.
profile_positions.title: Master student

profile_positions.description:
The assignment was part of an EU-project to investigate the effects of wind turbine sound on public health, in cooperation between the University Medical Center Groningen, the University of Malmö, and the University of Groningen’s Physics shop. My assignment consisted of developing an algorithm to determine the wind turbine sound level received for any location in the Netherlands, based on the locations and emission spectra of wind turbines in the Netherlands.
I collected information on the locations and types of wind turbines from local governments and data on their emission spectra from manufacturers. I used the method from the ‘Manual for measurements and calculations of industrial noise’ to develop an algorithm suitable for computation. I also coordinated the implementation of this algorithm in a web application with a software developer. 
The result was a publicly available online application, which was available for a year, where people could enter the location of their house, which produced the wind turbine sound level received there.
profile_positions.title: Bachelor student

profile_positions.description:
I worked as a journalist for the largest computer magazine in the Netherlands, with a monthly circulation of 230 000. I began work as a sideline job, but quickly developed from starter into a self-sufficient, reliable producer of well-readable articles. I was motivated to take on ever more assignments, sidelining the study for several years in the process.
Eventually I decided to prioritize the study over the job, and to complete my MSc in Physics.

As an IT journalist, my daily activities in included:
•	I established and maintained good relations with IT manufacturers to obtain pre-release product samples for review, information and news.
•	I participated in press events in numerous countries in Europe and in the US, to network, obtain information on the latest products, and learn about the latest and future technical developments from manufacturer’s technical representatives.
•	I arranged the pre-production samples and other components needed for review, before deadline, and if necessary with technical support to overcome technical issues with the pre-production samples.
•	I performed technical evaluations of IT products to determine their quality, performance and usefulness for our readers. Taking into account that what is interesting to a reviewer is not necessarily useful to a user, and that relations with business partners are closer than with readers, I nevertheless always performed reviews from the reader’s perspective.
•	I wrote articles on technical subjects for a non-technical audience, this included describing complex subjects in simpler terms, while maintaining accuracy.
profile_positions.title: IT journalist
